componenttext: No. The non-handset, the dongles, data cards and impact of tablets and other devices?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think if you are looking at the March quarter as compared to prior quarters, as Bill mentioned, we’ve got lower units. That’s a down quarter for QTL typically. But dongles, USBs as a percentage of total units, relatively constant quarter-over-quarte
componenttext: I think if you are looking at the March quarter as compared to prior quarters, as Bill mentioned, we’ve got lower units. That’s a down quarter for QTL typically. But dongles, USBs as a percentage of total units, relatively constant quarter-over-quarter from the prior quarter. The tablets, the new opportunities that we see coming might just be starting to kick in, in the quarters to come, but not really reflected too much in Q3.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Rod Hall from JPMorgan. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Rod Hall from JPMorgan. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I have just got a couple of a quick once. I wonder if you could just comment on the China MSM units. You said they were strong and I think at least we believe there was a crackdown in China on some of these white label producers, and I wondered, if you co
componenttext:
I have just got a couple of a quick once. I wonder if you could just comment on the China MSM units. You said they were strong and I think at least we believe there was a crackdown in China on some of these white label producers, and I wondered, if you could just say whether that has helped Chinese units on MSM, and whether you think that trend might continue?
My second question is on Snapdragon, and I wondered if you could just update us on the number of design wins you are standing at now? My third question is on mirasol, if you could just tell for the status of the second facility is and Paul, maybe just update us on where we are with demand on that for next year?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, maybe I’ll take the first two. The first one is about impacting China on the kind of crackdown on white label funds. I don’t know if we’ve seen direct impact to that. We need to see strong units out of China. We’re starting to see the begin
componenttext:
Steve, maybe I’ll take the first two. The first one is about impacting China on the kind of crackdown on white label funds. I don’t know if we’ve seen direct impact to that. We need to see strong units out of China. We’re starting to see the beginning of a mixed shift up-market from sort of voice and SMS-centric devices to more data-centric devices, which we think is a good trend moving forward.
But I think in terms of how the open market hits that, probably not as big an impact as you might think. I think there was a question too about an update on Snapdragon designs. We stopped tracking them probably as closely as we did in the early days. So it’s just a fair, broad sort of design flow across most of our OEMs. I think we’ve talked about 40 different customers and over 100 different designs. It’s very strong design-in flow right now. So we’re very pleased with the way that’s going.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On mirasol, in terms of second facility, we have released some relatively small amounts of money to get the process started. There are some negotiations that are ongoing both in terms of getting land and facilities in place there. So that looks like that
componenttext:
On mirasol, in terms of second facility, we have released some relatively small amounts of money to get the process started. There are some negotiations that are ongoing both in terms of getting land and facilities in place there. So that looks like that’s on target, and as we said that won’t be an impact through even next year. Next year we will be operating out of our first facility. We expect to be significantly supply constraints.
We have a number of partners, both the major name partners that are looking to build devices based off of the mirasol displays that we will have, and then also some other partners that will be doing and these will be primarily focused on that 5.7 inch more e-reader type of display that we have right now.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ehud Gelblum from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Ehud Gelblum from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick things. The uptick in the 10% sequential growth that we’re seeing in the market size, Bill and Steve, in your guidance next quarter of $26.5 billion to $28.5 billion, how much of that in your mind is coming from increased volume a
componenttext:
Just a couple of quick things. The uptick in the 10% sequential growth that we’re seeing in the market size, Bill and Steve, in your guidance next quarter of $26.5 billion to $28.5 billion, how much of that in your mind is coming from increased volume and how of that is coming from increased ASP or are you assuming essentially flat ASP and it’s all coming from volume?
Steve, also, your guidance for operating margin, you talked about the double-digit growth in the integrated chips and you talked about the full year operating margin now being at the high end of 23 to 24. Previously you talked about June being the trough and September being higher. Now, that June clearly is not in the trough. It turned out that March was the trough. Should we still look for September to be sequentially up from this or that’s not the way to look at it? We should look at it on a full year, just give me a sense sequentially?
And then, Paul, you made some interesting comments about MediaFLO in the discussion. If you could just elaborate a little bit and give us timing as to when you think you might see a resolution on that?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the market size, we’re going to stick with our new process of giving guidance on the total reported device sales, and then in three months or so, we’ll give you our best estimate on how that was broken down between units and ASP.
componenttext: On the market size, we’re going to stick with our new process of giving guidance on the total reported device sales, and then in three months or so, we’ll give you our best estimate on how that was broken down between units and ASP.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. On the operating margin, if you look at what we gave in the script, I think you can count it back into a number for the fourth quarter which I think is pretty consistent with what we’ve talked about before. The difference really is, for t
componenttext:
This is Steve. On the operating margin, if you look at what we gave in the script, I think you can count it back into a number for the fourth quarter which I think is pretty consistent with what we’ve talked about before. The difference really is, for the full year is what happened in Q3, and as you know, it came in a bit better than what we had expected. And I’ll refer a little back to what Bill had in his script we had some strength in North America. We also had some positive mix shift due the strength in smartphones, even inside of what we thought at the time we gave the outlook.
As we’ve talked about a number of times, the market is actually very difficult to measure and to predict in terms of mix. We are seeing customer demand pull in and ask for products inside of lead time. We are able to meet that demand. In this quarter, that’s been something that really positively impacted our numbers. It probably would have even been better had the rest of the supply chain been able to meet those demands as well, but I think it is well documented. Some of the other component supplies probably couldn’t do that. So, it’s really a positive mix shift that we’ve seen.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the MediaFLO process, in discussions with a number of different companies, we’ve been pleased by the response that we’ve gotten and the interest that we’ve had, although it is very early stages and really just going around now trying to
componenttext:
In terms of the MediaFLO process, in discussions with a number of different companies, we’ve been pleased by the response that we’ve gotten and the interest that we’ve had, although it is very early stages and really just going around now trying to understand the difference, things that different companies might be interested in relative to that business and relative to the spectrum also that we own. We haven’t really put a firm timeline in place.
So I would say it will get done in the next year, but I don’t think I can be much more specific than that. The process going forward includes a number of alternatives, so I wouldn’t necessarily jump to the conclusion that it will be done one way or another. There are different things that we’re trying to do in that process to see whether we can retain some ability to give advantages to our chipsets, for example, going forward. So, a lot of interesting discussions, and its early days, but we’re happy with the interest that we’ve gotten so far.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Maynard Um from UBS. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Maynard Um from UBS. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. Steve, can you just clarify your chipset margin commentary. I mean, given your increasing volumes, the favorable mix, with commentary about the pricing environment? Just curious, why you’re not seeing the greater leverage or even greater leverage in
componenttext:
Hi. Steve, can you just clarify your chipset margin commentary. I mean, given your increasing volumes, the favorable mix, with commentary about the pricing environment? Just curious, why you’re not seeing the greater leverage or even greater leverage incident next quarter?
And then Bill, Derek on the licensing side, can you talk about your royalty rate? It seems like Android is gaining significant share and not necessarily the lower royalty rate OEMs and also Apple presumably gaining shares. So, just wondering if there is a reason why you wouldn’t see your royalty rates increase as those licensees are gaining share? When do we get back to the mid to high 80% EBIT margins in that business?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Maynard, this is Steve. I’ll take the first half. So, we are seeing, I think, some improved operating margin metrics with the increase in volume. There continues to be a competitive pricing environment, but I think we are seeing a mix shift up certainly
componenttext: Maynard, this is Steve. I’ll take the first half. So, we are seeing, I think, some improved operating margin metrics with the increase in volume. There continues to be a competitive pricing environment, but I think we are seeing a mix shift up certainly better than had the smartphones not launched which I think is what we’ve been looking for. So, I think we are seeing the leverage. We are going to finish at the high end of that range. So, pretty much I think the years unfolded, largely the way that we thought. I think a little bit of an increase in this quarter relative to what we thought at this time last quarter.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Maynard, this is Bill. On your questions, based on the data we disclosed and then the implied royalty rate to calculate, you’d see a modest decrease in the quarter we just reported, sequential decrease. The primary driver there is infrastructure royalti
componenttext:
Maynard, this is Bill. On your questions, based on the data we disclosed and then the implied royalty rate to calculate, you’d see a modest decrease in the quarter we just reported, sequential decrease. The primary driver there is infrastructure royalties, which I think you understand. They tend to be kind of lumpy. But nothing structurally different is coming through there whatsoever.
In terms of a longer term view and getting back into the mid 80s, we’re working through our longer term plans now and we would certainly have plans to improve that operating margin, but we’ll consider maybe a little more color on that topic when we get to New York in November.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Simona Jankowski from Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Simona Jankowski from Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions for Steve. Steve, I think you are currently on 1 Gigahertz on your second generation of Snapdragon, and I think you mentioned in your sampling the 1.2 Gigahertz. From your competitive intelligence, do you expect your competitors
componenttext:
Just a couple of questions for Steve. Steve, I think you are currently on 1 Gigahertz on your second generation of Snapdragon, and I think you mentioned in your sampling the 1.2 Gigahertz. From your competitive intelligence, do you expect your competitors to be on that same kind of performance roadmap because it seems like in the last year or so you’ve all been relatively clustered in that speed, but curious if that’s going to gap one way or the other into the back half of the year?
And then just secondly, as LTE begins to ramp towards the end of this year, are those ASPs end market share for you consistent or different than what you have right now on 3G?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So, the first one about microprocessor competitiveness. We think there are designs and when we look at the competitive data, it has advanced both in terms of timing and performance on a core by core basis. If you look at the performance metrics even on br
componenttext:
So, the first one about microprocessor competitiveness. We think there are designs and when we look at the competitive data, it has advanced both in terms of timing and performance on a core by core basis. If you look at the performance metrics even on browsers and things like that, we feel that it actually even showed itself for the system level.
So, if you look at the performance even clock rate to clock rate, we think we have an advantage with the current design. We are working on speed enhancing those designs which you’ll see come out in the dual core designs. We also have a 1.5 and above gigahertz solutions also sampling that we can use. We’re coming out with the next generation micro-architecture which we think bumps it up substantially as well.
So, we feel that we have a leadership position into the future with regards to micro-architecture and microprocessors. I will say that the industry is filled with a lot of folks, either speed binning parts or doing things and comparing probably less apples to apples. But we feel very comfortable in terms of where we stand competitively with a commercial solution. So, hopefully that’s the answer to the one.
The second one was LTE ASPs. We do see uplift in terms of LTE ASP. The way that we positioned our product is that it comes out in standalone form and then it will be integrated in with our high-end smartphone solution. We think that LTE eventually will become a table stakes feature at the high end of flagships smartphones, and we’re positioning ourselves for that.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Ittai Kidron from Oppenheimer & Co. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Ittai Kidron from Oppenheimer & Co. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to dig again into the QCT margins. Given your annual guidance, it actually implies a sequential decline in margin in the next quarter or so. How should we think about that?Also, Steve, as we go into year, is this a level you expect us to be kind
componenttext:
Wanted to dig again into the QCT margins. Given your annual guidance, it actually implies a sequential decline in margin in the next quarter or so. How should we think about that?
Also, Steve, as we go into year, is this a level you expect us to be kind of ‘stuck on’ for some time or what would be the timing for you to start moving higher than the 24% that you are at right now?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would encourage you to perhaps maybe make the calculation again in terms of the fourth quarter. I don’t think we’ll see a decline and it probably depends on what your assumptions are in terms of some of the numbers. But I think we’ll be proba
componenttext:
Yes, I would encourage you to perhaps maybe make the calculation again in terms of the fourth quarter. I don’t think we’ll see a decline and it probably depends on what your assumptions are in terms of some of the numbers. But I think we’ll be probably closer to flat versus down.
With regards to next year, I think it’s a bit too early for us to be making comments about next year. We are pleased that we’re exiting kind of on the high end of our range and sort of with the right momentum, but I think will be in a better position to talk about next year in totality when we get to our analyst conference in November.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Very good. Just to follow up on Snapdragon. Are you experiencing shortages, specifically on that product?
componenttext: Very good. Just to follow up on Snapdragon. Are you experiencing shortages, specifically on that product?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we are not. We’ve been supported very well by our foundry partners for that product. In fact, in some cases, we have delivered to some OEMs, 300% of their lead time forecast. So, we’ve been able to actually move very, very aggressively to meet the
componenttext: No, we are not. We’ve been supported very well by our foundry partners for that product. In fact, in some cases, we have delivered to some OEMs, 300% of their lead time forecast. So, we’ve been able to actually move very, very aggressively to meet their needs. I don’t believe the rest of the industry is able to move as quickly as perhaps we are, but we have been able to supply those products to meet customer needs.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: James Faucette from Pacific Crest. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: James Faucette from Pacific Crest. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to direct one question to Steven in the competitive environment for chipsets. You indicated that you’re still seeing some competitive pressures, maybe from pricing or even gigahertz in response to Simona’s question. My question is, how would
componenttext:
I wanted to direct one question to Steven in the competitive environment for chipsets. You indicated that you’re still seeing some competitive pressures, maybe from pricing or even gigahertz in response to Simona’s question. My question is, how would you compare the competitive environment now, say versus a year ago? Are you feeling more comfortable, less, or do you think it’s about the same?
And then, maybe a question for Bill or Paul, as far as the large amount of cash, particularly offshore cash, I know you’re using some of that in terms of the spectrum acquisition in India, but can you talk a little bit about options that you may be exploring or how important that is to you to at least try to find a way to do some more flexible or be more flexible with that? Thank you much.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: James, this is Steve. I’ll take the first part of that. With regards to pricing, it’s really of three components. There’s customer mix, there’s product mix, and there’s really kind of pricing. Customer mix and product mix, we believe is trending
componenttext:
James, this is Steve. I’ll take the first part of that. With regards to pricing, it’s really of three components. There’s customer mix, there’s product mix, and there’s really kind of pricing. Customer mix and product mix, we believe is trending positively. I mentioned about the diversity of customers earlier on. I think that is something that actually helps us to a certain extent.
In terms of pricing, it’s still a very competitive environment as semiconductors always are. Relative to where we were a year ago, I think a year ago we had a number of people who were probably entering into the market and were probably a bit more aggressive than what we see today. A lot of them have already entered, have already played their hand to some extent.
There’s always continual pressure as products get upgraded, but I think it’s probably a little bit less aggressive relative to where it was let’s say three quarters ago. You can see that I think in our ASP trends as well if you look at sort of a sequential change in our ASP. But it continues to be something that we have to manage and have to work our way and innovate our way out of.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the offshore cash and obviously we’re using it in areas for managing the business. Things like eventually the India spectrum, mirasol investments as well, clearly, we also invest that money offshore. The returns off of that are onshore and w
componenttext:
In terms of the offshore cash and obviously we’re using it in areas for managing the business. Things like eventually the India spectrum, mirasol investments as well, clearly, we also invest that money offshore. The returns off of that are onshore and we use that for things like dividends and share buyback.
But in addition, we’ve been having a number of discussions lately with the government about the opportunities for repatriation, because we feel very strongly that with the amount of offshore cash that a lot of U.S. companies have that really could be almost a private sector stimulus if there was a way to bring that money back and incentivize companies to bring that money back and put it to use in the United States.
So we’ve had discussions around whether that could be used for CapEx and things like building factories in the United States, whether we could use it for improving or increasing R&D in the United States. We have also had discussions about whether it could be brought back for doing things like providing dividends to shareholders, and you do get some push back.
There is a perception in Washington that previous repatriation that happened did not result in job growth and so forth. In fact, I guess, some companies that had repatriated money had layoffs after that and so that left a bad taste in the mouth of many politicians and regulators. But I think, that there are arguments to be made there and we will continue to make those kinds of arguments, but in as well as doing that obviously we’ll continue to use it for investments and for business purposes.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Edward Snyder from Charter Equity Research. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Edward Snyder from Charter Equity Research. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things here. Channel inventory seems to be remaining low and I know you’ve got it for more of the same even as you’re coming off of the trough period in demand here. Is this permanent dislocation in inventory or is there some structural is
componenttext:
A couple of things here. Channel inventory seems to be remaining low and I know you’ve got it for more of the same even as you’re coming off of the trough period in demand here. Is this permanent dislocation in inventory or is there some structural issues that are holding you down as you think may revert to the mean as we go forward?
And then Steve, is it fair to assume that a higher mix of your slim modem shipments like we’re seeing in Motorola’s Droid products and there has been rumored that it’s going to be in the Apple iPhone, that will push margins back down to lower end of your ASIC guidance, and then Snapdragon pulled it to the top. I am just trying to get a handle on the mix.
The final question, I am sorry, for three here. Is there any visibility on LTE device for handsets, when that might start sampling, maybe next year or even if you can block it into a half of your segment? That would be great.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: On the channel inventory, I think you’ve heard us, we’ve felt that channel inventory has been at the low end of its historical range for some time now. We think that was largely driven by concern over the world economy. I still think there is an eleme
componenttext: On the channel inventory, I think you’ve heard us, we’ve felt that channel inventory has been at the low end of its historical range for some time now. We think that was largely driven by concern over the world economy. I still think there is an element of that in various parties thinking. But, having said that, I think it’s somewhat constrained today also by the fact that there are other parts of the chain we’re doing well and other parts of the chain of the phone supply that are experiencing shortages.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: The question about the modem mix, and I’ll try not to talk too much about any particular customer or potential customer. But the way, if you look at our product portfolio, we essentially have high-end smartphone solutions, we have kind of mass market sm
componenttext:
The question about the modem mix, and I’ll try not to talk too much about any particular customer or potential customer. But the way, if you look at our product portfolio, we essentially have high-end smartphone solutions, we have kind of mass market smartphone solutions and feature phone, and then we have modems. The modem tier really depending on whether you’re taking sort of last year’s modem or this year’s modem or next year’s modem, there’s a pretty big difference in terms of pricing. We do get paid we think for our leadership of modems.
Depending on how particular OEM that’s using a standalone modem, which modem tier they select, that influences the ASP quite a bit. Probably the modem tier that we use in sort of mass market USB tends to be a little bit below what we see in the handset tier. So, short answer to your question, it really depends on what the OEM picks in terms of how it will affect our ASP.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Stacy Rasgon from Sanford Bernstein. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Stacy Rasgon from Sanford Bernstein. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones around the operating margins and the royalty rates. So, first of all, we saw QTL operating margins, it looked to me like they came down about 500 basis points and we have the royalty rate, as you mentioned, compressed a bit, and I think you
componenttext:
Two quick ones around the operating margins and the royalty rates. So, first of all, we saw QTL operating margins, it looked to me like they came down about 500 basis points and we have the royalty rate, as you mentioned, compressed a bit, and I think you said it was due to infrastructure.
I was wondering if you could give me a little bit of color on what drove such a large decline in the QTL operating margin. Also, for your guidance that the full year royalty rate would be about where Q4 ‘09 was last year. By my recollection, that was about 3.4%, I think. Would that imply further compression in royalty rates in Q4?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Stacy, Bill Keitel here. On the QTL op-margin, two factors there that we’d mention. One is that we’re recording revenues now for products that licensees shipped in the March quarter. March quarter tends to be the low quarter coming off the holiday sea
componenttext:
Stacy, Bill Keitel here. On the QTL op-margin, two factors there that we’d mention. One is that we’re recording revenues now for products that licensees shipped in the March quarter. March quarter tends to be the low quarter coming off the holiday season. So, revenues were low in QTL just from a seasonality standpoint, so that affected the margins, one. Two, was that, more of our legal expenses and patent filing expenses were impacting licensing business this quarter.
On your second question, the royalty rate, yes, we have been saying that we expect the royalty rate as you calculated based on the information we provide for this year to about equal the rate that we reported going out of fiscal ‘09. It ebbs and flows a bit from quarter-to-quarter for things like infrastructure payments or the mix of product, but on balance we think it’s going to be about equal for the full year. And then, of course, remember too that that rate is understated because of two licensee disputes that we remain confident in it and it really just a matter of time before we are able to report those revenues.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Kulbinder Garcha from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead with your question.
componenttext: Kulbinder Garcha from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead with your question.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up there on the licensing margin. Is this cost structure on licensing, I’m not clear on. Is it permanently higher for a period of time or is it just temporary in this quarter. I’m trying to figure out where the margins bounced back quite
componenttext: Just a follow-up there on the licensing margin. Is this cost structure on licensing, I’m not clear on. Is it permanently higher for a period of time or is it just temporary in this quarter. I’m trying to figure out where the margins bounced back quite quickly in licensing? And when this first came about, I think in January we seemed confident it will get settled this year there’s a kind of a time horizon at when it could come back. Could you say, for example, you feel comfortable whether it’d be within 18 months you get these revenues and earnings back?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Kulbinder, on your first question in terms of the rate, no, I wouldn’t see anything structural here. Seasonality on revenues this quarter for licensing business tends to be the low quarters. So, I mean, that’s constant, but I don’t think that’s yo
componenttext:
Kulbinder, on your first question in terms of the rate, no, I wouldn’t see anything structural here. Seasonality on revenues this quarter for licensing business tends to be the low quarters. So, I mean, that’s constant, but I don’t think that’s your definition or what you’re trying to describe here as structural. In terms of fees we incur for legal defense of our business, it’s sometimes QCT business is incurring a higher level in that, other times it could be the licensing business. Overall, those fees are down substantially if you look back a couple of year or two. But right now, the licensing business; couple of matters we’re dealing with are focused on licensing.
And then in terms of the revenue, in the past we’ve said that it’s in the range of approximately $200 million, we think as of the end of this fiscal year that revenue that’s due to us that we expect to ultimately collect. The number has not changed substantially, but the probability at which we are including revenues for fiscal ‘10 has been reducing as times gone by. Again, we are very confident that we’ll ultimately be able to forward these revenues. Timing can be a difficult thing to pinpoint, but overall I think we are making progress.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So, we actually think we have an acquisition cost advantage to being integrated. That acquisition cost advantage tends to be best suited for the die sizes that you need to support a mass market feature phone or mass market smartphone. So, we actually view
componenttext:
So, we actually think we have an acquisition cost advantage to being integrated. That acquisition cost advantage tends to be best suited for the die sizes that you need to support a mass market feature phone or mass market smartphone. So, we actually view ourselves as having an advantage. What margin that our competitors are willing to take ultimately determines what the price is to the OEM, but we feel we have an acquisition cost advantage.
There are a number of other players who support integrated solutions. They tend not to have to the same breadth of technology either up and down a particular technology like WCDMA. They may not have the same number of tiers and so they therefore can’t cover as broad a product portfolio with a large OEM or we don’t think they have the ability to stay with us as we drive technology at the speed of which we think we can. So, there’s no shortage of people who want to compete in this area, but we feel that our core strength really are the things that will be rewarded by the customer base.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, Steve, are there any motivations to kind of drive the costs down for Snapdragon so that you could drive unit growth or not just yet?
componenttext: As a follow-up, Steve, are there any motivations to kind of drive the costs down for Snapdragon so that you could drive unit growth or not just yet?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, there’s not a policy for that. We obviously make that on an opportunity by opportunity basis. We think the market is just beginning to make this shift and these categories are just launching. So I think it’s at the point where there is a pr
componenttext: Obviously, there’s not a policy for that. We obviously make that on an opportunity by opportunity basis. We think the market is just beginning to make this shift and these categories are just launching. So I think it’s at the point where there is a premium applied to these types of devices and as we need to do that we will do that. We will be putting ourselves in a position of, we think, relative strength as we move to 28-nanometer. We will be able to drive integration we think even faster than the competitors, so we’ll be even better positioned as we make that node transition.

componenttext: The question I had was, given that the majority of these smartphones have kind of standalone application process, is Qualcomm averse to the idea of offering a standalone processor? Along those lines, do you see a price point cut off where most of the handset guys are looking for integrated solutions versus standalone?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say this, our data probably shows a different trend, which is that, if you look worldwide and take out the Apple iPhone, the trend really tends to be more toward integrated than disintegrated when you look at it, if that trend even becomes stronge
componenttext:
I would say this, our data probably shows a different trend, which is that, if you look worldwide and take out the Apple iPhone, the trend really tends to be more toward integrated than disintegrated when you look at it, if that trend even becomes stronger as you go to phones with a retail ASP lower that $200.
So, it’s really in that mass market range where you tend to see the integrated winning and you could see that across a number of different OEMs. I think sometimes, we tend to make conclusions based off of what we see in North America, and worldwide there is quite bit of volume across, particularly Android volume, that shows a very different trend, and we definitely see that in our order flow.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to thank everybody for joining us again this afternoon, and we are really pleased with the way the quarter turned out and happy to be able to raise guidance. I think that’s really a reflection of these favorable trends. We’ve been talking about
componenttext:
I want to thank everybody for joining us again this afternoon, and we are really pleased with the way the quarter turned out and happy to be able to raise guidance. I think that’s really a reflection of these favorable trends. We’ve been talking about with the smartphone volumes really starting to ramp and Snapdragon starting to ramp with 3G becoming global and with the new technology starting to ramp, it turns into things like record MSM shipments and better mix, and also better device ASPs.
So, we’ve been happy to have the opportunity to return capital to our shareholders in the face of what I think was very bearish sentiment about the company. The other thing is that we are able also to continue to really invest in new technologies and products, and I think that positions us very well for the future. So, thanks very much everyone.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Today's call will include prepared remarks by Dr. Paul Jacobs; Steven Mollenkopf; and Bill Keitel. In addition, Steve Altman, Don Rosenberg and Derek Aberle will join the question-and-answer session. An Internet pr
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Today's call will include prepared remarks by Dr. Paul Jacobs; Steven Mollenkopf; and Bill Keitel. In addition, Steve Altman, Don Rosenberg and Derek Aberle will join the question-and-answer session. An Internet presentation and audio broadcast accompany this call and you access them by visiting www.qualcomm.com.
During this conference call, if we use any non-GAAP financial measures as defined by the SEC in Regulation G, you can find the required reconciliations to GAAP on our website. I'd also like to direct you to our 10-Q and earnings release, which were filed and furnished, respectively, with the SEC today and are available on our website.
We may make forward-looking statements relating to our expectations and other future events that may differ materially from Qualcomm's actual results. Please review our SEC filings for a detailed presentation of each of our businesses and associated risk and other important factors that may cause our actual results to differ from these forward-looking statements.
And now it is my pleasure to introduce QUALCOMM's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Dr. Paul Jacobs.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Warren, and good afternoon, everyone. Our financial performance this quarter was ahead of our expectations. It was driven by record MSM chipset shipments, favorable product mix and continued strong demand for 3G devices around the world. Looking f
componenttext:
Thanks, Warren, and good afternoon, everyone. Our financial performance this quarter was ahead of our expectations. It was driven by record MSM chipset shipments, favorable product mix and continued strong demand for 3G devices around the world. Looking forward, we continue to see healthy CDMA-based device growth approximately 23% in calendar year 2010, and are pleased to be raising our revenue and earnings guidance for the fiscal year. I'd also like to highlight that during the third quarter and the first few weeks of our current quarter, we repurchased an additional $1.3 billion of our common stock, bringing our cumulative repurchases to $3 billion in this fiscal year.
This is an exciting time in the wireless industry. Although some global economic uncertainty remains, our business is extremely well-positioned to capitalize on some very positive industry trends. Specifically, mobile wireless data usage continues to expand rapidly, a rather transformative stage in the industry as people increasingly use their 3G devices to stay connected. New network technologies are coming online to meet the demand for more capacity. With the recent issuance of licenses in India, the 3G footprint is now global. 
Finally, we're seeing the emergence of new 3G-connected device types come to market. And QUALCOMM's scale and breadth of technologies position us to uniquely capitalize on these opportunities. A broad licensing program and our semiconductor expertise in managing the complex performance in power management demands of the market really set us apart.
Moving into some specific. Global wireless subscribers recently surpassed the 5 billion milestone according to Wireless Intelligence, just over 1 billion of these being 3G. According to the GSA and CDG, approximately 85% of the world's networks now support 3G. With networks in place and a healthy demand for data services, we expect the global migration from 2G to 3G to continue.
Smartphones remain one of the fastest-growing segments in wireless as evidenced by the focus major OEMs are placing on this device category. According to Informa, one in every five phones sold globally in 2010 will be a smartphone. By 2012, approximately one in every three is projected to be a smartphone. Additionally, we're seeing carriers continue to experiment with variable data pricing plans, which will help spur data growth and drive demand for data-capable devices. Our broad family chipsets, including the cost-effective QSC single chips designed for emerging markets, as well as our industry-leading Snapdragon products, which support a wide range of operating systems and multimedia capabilities, position us well to assist our partners in creating devices across all tiers in the market.
We recently held our first annual uplink conference in San Diego, which provided a forum for developers and partners to learn about new initiatives within QUALCOMM and to create new business opportunities. The event was a success and brought together more than 2,100 attendees from around the world. We focused on our support for multiple operating systems and how developers can better optimize their applications to work with our solutions, as well as how Brew MP will help bring the smartphone experience to the masses.
Brew MP is gaining traction with operators such as AT&T, America Movil, Korea Telecom and China Telecom, in addition to the traditional Brew operators. To meet the growing demand for wireless data, more license spectrum needs to be made available for mobile broadband around the world. Operators are making significant spectrum and capital investments to keep pace with consumer demand. And we're very encouraged that in just the past few months, India, Germany, France, Denmark, the Netherlands along with Mexico and Colombia have all conducted major spectrum auctions. 
On the technology front, operators continue to invest in network enhancements, the GSA reported that almost all operators have launched WCDMA have upgraded to HSPA, and approximately 1/3 of these operators are committed to deploying the higher data rates with HSPA+. In addition, 80 operators have  committed to deploy LTE, up from 64 just a few months back.
Moving to the region, China represents a significant 3G opportunity with only 12% of the approximately 800 million subscribers using 3G according to Wireless Intelligence and operator reports. The breath of 3G devices being made available to consumers across China continue to grow, fueling demand for 3G adoption. China Telecom has been adding more than 3 million CDMA2000 subscribers per month this year, thus further energizing and leading the global CDMA2000 ecosystem. At the end of June, they hosted the China Telecom CDMA2000 Ecosystem Conference, an event that attracted several thousand attendees and served as a venue for ecosystem players to develop business opportunities relating to new devices and technologies.
At the event, China Telecom encouraged device manufacturers to use Brew MP as an operating system for low and mid-tier smartphones and shared expectation that smartphones will make up to 50% of 2011 new handset models. 
Other topics of discussion included QChat, 1x Advanced and EV-DO, including Rev B. With over 71 million CDMA subscribers on their network, China Telecom is on a path to becoming the largest CDMA2000 operator in the world.
In North America, we continue to see a bifurcation of demand with growth at both the high-end and low-end. Smartphones continue to define innovation in this highly competitive region with some of the hottest devices incorporating our Snapdragon solution, including HTC's Incredible and Evo. As well, prepaid continues to show signs of strength and several operators reported strong prepaid numbers in calendar Q1.
We're also seeing some encouraging signs with replacement rates as consumers upgrade to new devices. Verizon reported that 8.6% of their postpaid base upgraded in the first quarter representing an increase of almost 15% from a year ago. In Europe, we do remain cautious on short term growth prospects, but within this backdrop, we are confident in the continued 3G growth and are encouraged by several favorable trends. Leading operators are pushing smartphone growth and are actively deploying HSPA+ as an evolution for 3G networks. According to the GSA, the number of commercial HSPA+ networks in Europe jumped from eight to 34 in the past year. On their last earnings call, Vodaphone Group reported that their current smartphone sales were 30% of their total mix and they intend to grow the smartphone mix to 70% or more by their fiscal 2012.
We're also continuing to see strength in 3G USB dongles. A competition is going to drive 3G price points lower and into prepaid as evidenced by the launch of T-Mobile's Android-based  Pulse Mini and Samsung's Pocket 3G. And lastly, according to Wireless Intelligence, 3G penetration in Eastern Europe is approximately 10% leaving strong growth opportunities ahead.
Turning to India, the 3G auction process was completed with seven carriers being awarded spectrum. Consumers will benefit as these carriers compete to provide compelling 3G services and product offerings. Based on operator commentary, new 3G networks could be in service as soon as the end of this year. The expanded 3G footprint in India will provide us an opportunity to address the higher tier that was previously served by 2G devices. 
In June, we won a 20 megahertz slot of spectrum in the four telecom circles in the Indian Broadband Wireless Access auction. Our strategy with this spectrum is to facilitate the deployment of TD-LTE technology in combination with 3G, provide a clear technology roadmap for Indian operators and help foster a worldwide 3G/LTE ecosystem.
With respect to our FLO TV business, we are engaged in discussions with a number of partners regarding the future direction of the business. We are considering a number of alternatives and we will update you as appropriate. 
So in conclusion, our fiscal year revenues are broadly in line with our original expectations at the outset of the year with earnings per share trending ahead. While revenue growth this year is below what we expect of our business longer-term, we're confident that the investments we are making in new products and technologies, as well as the strategic pricing initiatives we have taken this year to maintain and grow our business, will allow us to achieve our long-term growth objective.
That concludes my comments and I will now turn the call over to Steve Mollenkopf.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. Our QCT business continues to execute well and I'm pleased to be able to share some highlights from the third fiscal quarter of 2010. We had a record quarter shipping approximately 103 million MSMs, which represents an increase of 11% ove
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. Our QCT business continues to execute well and I'm pleased to be able to share some highlights from the third fiscal quarter of 2010. We had a record quarter shipping approximately 103 million MSMs, which represents an increase of 11% over the previous quarter. This increase was driven by our leadership in smartphones, particularly UMTS, as customers embraced our integrated roadmap, including our 7000 and 8000 series chipsets, and by continued strong demand for our data-centric products.
In total, QCT revenues were up 10% sequentially, reflecting these strong unit volumes and relatively stable prices. The investments we have made in our smartphone portfolio have put us in a leadership position across all tiers and geographies. This was evidenced by our growth of our 7k and 8k series chipset shipments of nearly 50% sequentially. We believe we have gained significant share in mobile application processors in the past two years with our internal data showing that our share at application processors has more than doubled in this period. Our flagship Snapdragon brand has become the industry benchmark with over 15 new designs launching this past quarter.
In the rapidly growing Android segment, we are continuing our leadership position in both modems and application processors. Since launching the world's first Android device almost three years ago, we now have over 40 commercially launched designs spanning multiple price tiers and form factors, ranging from smartphones to smartbook devices. QUALCOMM's chipsets are in some of the most popular devices this quarter, including the HTC Incredible, the HTC Evo, the Sony Ericsson XPERIA X10 and Lenovo's LePhone. We expect our success with Android devices to continue as we expand our support for Android across all tiers of our MSM. Today, our partners have more than 50 device designs in progress based on our platform. Our current generation of Snapdragon chips are shipping in volume and we continue to expand our industry-leading portfolio. This quarter, we sampled our Snapdragon dual core 1.2 gigahertz chipset with advanced GPU and multimedia capabilities.
The industry is going through multiple modem technology transitions from 2G to 3G in some countries and 3G to 4G in others. We believe these technology transitions are opportunities for us to continue to demonstrate our strength in both modem development and systems integration. Our MDM9000 series, 3G LTE multimode chips are available now. We expect to see data devices based on these chipsets offered commercially before the end of the year, followed by smartphones and other smart-connected devices starting next year.
We had incorporated TD-LTE into all of our 3G LTE chipsets to align with and leverage our recent win of BWA spectrum in the 2.3 gigahertz band in India, and our worldwide carrier relationships. We continue to focus on advanced wireless WAN technologies, deliver backwards compatibility on our chipsets with all air interfaces and global multimode capabilities, which is an important and growing strategic advantage for us versus the competition. 
Looking ahead, demand for our chipset products remains strong. For our fourth fiscal quarter, we estimate MSM shipments will increase to approximately 106 to 111 million units driven primarily by greater demand for smartphones and strength in China and North America. The chipset market continues to be very competitive and the pricing environment is mostly consistent with our expectations at the onset of the year. As always, the demand profile across our broad product portfolio is a key driver of our results. Based on our latest estimates of this demand mix, we expect QCT operating profit for fiscal 2010 to be close to the high end of our prior guidance of 22% to 24%.
We are pleased with the execution across teams in QCT and we look forward to the opportunities ahead. Our chipset portfolio aligns with device trends today and in the future, with industry-leading chipsets for HSPA+; multimode 3G LTE; integrated Snapdragon solutions for tiered smartbooks, smartphones and tablets; as well as low-cost solutions for the unique needs in emerging markets. 
That concludes my comments. I will now turn the call over to Bill Keitel.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, everybody. I'll began with the highlights of our third quarter results. Revenues were $2.7 billion with the high-end of our prior guidance. The pro forma earnings per share were $0.57 exceeding our prior guidance on the stre
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Good afternoon, everybody. I'll began with the highlights of our third quarter results. Revenues were $2.7 billion with the high-end of our prior guidance. The pro forma earnings per share were $0.57 exceeding our prior guidance on the strength of record MSM shipments. In our QTL segment, revenues were $847 million. Total reported device sales by our licensees was $25.2 billion for activity in the March quarter, up approximately 19% year-over-year and consistent with our expectations at the outset of the quarter.
We estimate that approximately 134 to 138 million subscriber units were shipped by our licensees at an average selling price of approximately $183  to $189. We believe the average selling price increased sequentially driven by higher end devices, notably smartphones.
QCT shipped a record 103 million chipsets this quarter. QCT's operating margin was 24%, better than our expectation at the outset of the quarter, driven by greater phone volume and favorable product mix related to smartphone demand trends, as well as relative strength in North America. Operating cash flow was $951 million and our cash and marketable securities balance was $17.6 billion at the end of the quarter, with $5.9 billion onshore and $11.7 billion offshore.
During the third fiscal quarter and the first few weeks of this current quarter, we returned $1.6 billion of capital to our shareholders, including dividends paid at $309 million and $1.3 billion of shares repurchased. Our remaining stock purchase authority is now $1.7 billion. Our pro forma tax rate was approximately 19% in the third fiscal quarter, and we estimate our pro forma annual tax rate will be approximately 20% to 21% for fiscal 2010.
As Paul mentioned, we won spectrum in the recent India BWA auction for a total cost of approximately $1.1 billion. Due to local regulatory restrictions, we financed the payment for the spectrum on a short-term basis with a rupee bank loan. We expect to form a partnership and finalize the partnership capital structure, including use of our offshore cash by the end of the calendar year. And we plan to ultimately exit the venture.
Now turning to our guidance. For CDMA-based device shipments, we continue to see strong growth in global 3G device sales and we are reaffirming our 2010 forecast. We estimate that between 600 million and 650 million CDMA devices will be shipped in 2010, reflecting approximately 18% to 28% growth year-over-year based on the 508 million midpoint of our 2009 estimate. Our estimate for CDMA channel inventory is consistent with our prior expectations as we continue to estimate that it's at the lower end of the historical range and will remain so the rest of this year.
We are raising our revenue guidance and now expect fiscal 2010 revenues to be in the range of approximately $10.7 billion to $11 billion. We are raising our earnings per share guidance and now expect pro forma earnings per share to be in the range of approximately $2.33 to $2.37. We estimate that the average selling price of CDMA-based devices for fiscal 2010 will be approximately $184 to $188, a slight increase above our prior guidance. We continue to estimate that the average QTL royalty rate fiscal 2010 as you calculate it with the information we provide, and excluding the one-time Samsung catch-up in the first fiscal quarter, to be approximately equal to the rate of our fourth fiscal quarter 2009. The rate continues to be understated due to two licensee disputes.  We are reaffirming our estimate or pro forma combined R&D and SG&A expense to grow approximately 4% year-over-year. 
Looking ahead to the fourth fiscal quarter, we estimate revenues be in the range of approximately $2.67 billion to $2.93 billion. We estimate pro forma earnings per share for the fourth fiscal quarter to be approximately $0.55 to $0.59. We estimate that June quarter total reported device sales, which will be reported later this quarter by our licensees, will be approximately $26.5 billion to $28.5 billion, up approximately 5% to 13% sequentially and 6% to 14% year-over-year. Our current estimates for QTL fourth fiscal quarter revenue and gross margin are contributing to QUALCOMM's raised guidance. Although we now see some foreign exchange impact, notably the Euro, it is more than offset by higher than expected ASPs.
We anticipate that QCT will ship a new record of approximately 106 million to 111 million MSM units during the September quarter. We anticipate fourth fiscal quarter pro forma combined R&D and SG&A expenses will increase sequentially, approximately 1% to 2%. 
In closing, we're pleased with the progress we're seeing in the second half of this fiscal year. That does concludes my comments. I'll now turn the call back to Dr. Warren Kneeshaw.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. Before we go into our question-and-answer session, I'd like to remind our participants that our goal in this call is to address as many questions as possible before we run out of time. I would encourage you to limit your questions to one
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. Before we go into our question-and-answer session, I'd like to remind our participants that our goal in this call is to address as many questions as possible before we run out of time. I would encourage you to limit your questions to one per caller. 
Operator, we're ready for questions.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Tim Luke with Barclays Capital.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve or Bill, it looked like you saw a list in your operating margins for the Chip business, as well as some improved volume. Could you talk about some of the factors that are leading to that improvement in the operating margin and how you may see the op
componenttext: Steve or Bill, it looked like you saw a list in your operating margins for the Chip business, as well as some improved volume. Could you talk about some of the factors that are leading to that improvement in the operating margin and how you may see the operating margin dynamic going forward. Do you see a stronger Snapdragon shipment? I'd also just be grateful, Bill, if you might be able to clarify. It separately looked like the gross margin for the licensing business was slightly lower in the quarter. Could you clarify what might have contributed to that?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Steve. I'll take the first half of that question there. What we saw in this quarter sequentially was an uptick in our smartphone platforms, which is a little bit better mix for us in terms of pricing and the value that we get on a chipset-by-chips
componenttext: This is Steve. I'll take the first half of that question there. What we saw in this quarter sequentially was an uptick in our smartphone platforms, which is a little bit better mix for us in terms of pricing and the value that we get on a chipset-by-chipset basis. So in particular, as I said in my script, we saw that our integrated solution really jumped up 50% actually on a quarter-by-quarter basis. We also saw pretty strong growth in UMTS, which I think was beneficial as well. Looking forward into the fourth quarter, we expect to see again double-digit percentage growth on a sequential basis on our integrated smartphone chipset. So we think we're benefiting from a positive mix shift.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tim, on the QTL side, the quarter we just reported for QTL were for shipments that occurred in the March quarter, which is our typical seasonally down quarter, and that was no different for this year. So you just got less volume going through in the quart
componenttext: Tim, on the QTL side, the quarter we just reported for QTL were for shipments that occurred in the March quarter, which is our typical seasonally down quarter, and that was no different for this year. So you just got less volume going through in the quarter that we just reported now. On the operating margin line, there was also an increment in legal and patent expenses, additional patent expenses for additional patent filings.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian Modoff from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Brian Modoff from Deutsche Bank.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the pricing environment overall you raised your overall ASP by the low end, by $2. Is this kind or more what you talked about earlier in the year where you expected the overall environment or the overall mix to improve in the back half
componenttext: Can you talk about the pricing environment overall you raised your overall ASP by the low end, by $2. Is this kind or more what you talked about earlier in the year where you expected the overall environment or the overall mix to improve in the back half driven by better sales in some of the more mature markets? And then Paul, you mentioned about returning to your long-term revenue growth target on the top line. Can you kind of talk about what would be the drivers that would create revenue growth again for QUALCOMM and when we might seeing that?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Bill. To your first question, yes, that is what we're seeing. We had expected in the second half of this year richer devices to be shipping. And in fact, that's what we're seeing.
componenttext: Brian, this is Bill. To your first question, yes, that is what we're seeing. We had expected in the second half of this year richer devices to be shipping. And in fact, that's what we're seeing.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So we're expecting to see -- although we haven't put out our projections for the next year so I may be cautious. But we've been talking about getting back to the mid-teens kind of growth rate over the medium term. And really, where that's coming from is s
componenttext: So we're expecting to see -- although we haven't put out our projections for the next year so I may be cautious. But we've been talking about getting back to the mid-teens kind of growth rate over the medium term. And really, where that's coming from is some of the most things that you've heard about this quarter or next quarter in terms of new device types trending towards smartphones. You've heard about new geographies coming online particularly China and now India moving to allow us to sell into the higher tier. So a number of really good trends I think coming online, those will really impact our top and bottom lines.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tal Liani from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Tal Liani from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I have two questions. The first one is about the better ASPs that you mentioned, Bill. Can you discuss regions? Is the ASP better in all regions, or is it mostly in countries with smartphones? And also, most of the currency headwinds is in Europe, of cour
componenttext: I have two questions. The first one is about the better ASPs that you mentioned, Bill. Can you discuss regions? Is the ASP better in all regions, or is it mostly in countries with smartphones? And also, most of the currency headwinds is in Europe, of course, because of the euro. So you can you discuss also ASP trends in Europe versus other regions? So that's the first question. The second question is about semiconductors. You mentioned on the call now, in one of the Q&A -- you mentioned on the call that you expect double-digit growth in integrated chips. On the other hand, we hear from your customers, public announcements from Samsung, that they launched announced Android phones based on their own Hummingbird and LG endorsing OMAP [ Open Multimedia Application Platform] we hear more and more from your customers about other vendors. And the question is, what is the risk that your content in smartphones, chip content is going to go down in value because maybe you're going to be shifted more towards just the modem part versus an integrated solution?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tal, it's Bill. I'll take the first question on the ASPs. First, on the Euro, the FX impact of the Euro was about offset by the favorable ASP that we saw in Europe. So revenues coming into licensing business for Europe as a whole is about a wash between t
componenttext: Tal, it's Bill. I'll take the first question on the ASPs. First, on the Euro, the FX impact of the Euro was about offset by the favorable ASP that we saw in Europe. So revenues coming into licensing business for Europe as a whole is about a wash between the FX impact and the favorable ASP. On the broader front, in terms of ASPs for the quarter we just reported, we saw about a half-dozen regions with improved ASPs quarter to quarter, including China, Europe, India, Korea, Latin America. A little more mix is our expectation going into the September quarter. Just about half and half is our expectation on terms of improved ASPs relative to a modest decline.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the second half of the question about competitiveness on the smartphone area, if you look at our customer makeup, we have a very different feedback coming from the customers that I think you represented in your question. I mentioned in the script a
componenttext: And on the second half of the question about competitiveness on the smartphone area, if you look at our customer makeup, we have a very different feedback coming from the customers that I think you represented in your question. I mentioned in the script about launching 15 different Snapdragon designs over the last quarter alone, there's a fair bit of customer diversity there who actually, which I think helps us. I think is somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 to 11 different customers actually launching those products. We also had a significant increase from a new customer who's ramping European customer, which I think helps us in terms of diversifying the business. The other trend that we're seeing both strategically, as well as in our numbers is the move to more mass-market smartphones. As they move that direction, we think it actually advantages us in terms of our integrated solution just because the only way that you can get to that cost point is by integrating. I know there's differences of opinion on this. But as you get to a lower-priced phone, the phone that actually replaces a feature phone, which is where a lot of the volume comes from, they tend to go integrated. And we see that in our order flow as well. And as I mentioned, we had almost 50% growth sequential growth from Q2 to Q3 and we expect that to continue at double-digit percentage rate from Q3 to Q4.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Tim Long from Banc of Montreal.
componenttext: Tim Long from Banc of Montreal.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: First, Bill, if you could clarify on the guidance, I'm trying to put these together. So I'm looking at the midpoint of the royalty revenues up 9% sequentially March to June. And your MSMs look like midpoint is up 5% June to September, share count probably
componenttext: First, Bill, if you could clarify on the guidance, I'm trying to put these together. So I'm looking at the midpoint of the royalty revenues up 9% sequentially March to June. And your MSMs look like midpoint is up 5% June to September, share count probably down because of the buyback. How is the midpoint of earnings guidance flat if you could just tell us what some of the negatives are to that? And then secondly, if you could just talk a little bit about the non-handset market, what's going on there. My sense is given that unit numbers you're talking about in Q1 that might have been down pretty well in the first quarter, in the March quarter? So could you talk about the dynamics in dongles and USBs and what you think happens as other devices, like tablets, really start to hit your numbers?

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, Tim, on the first part of your question, in terms of the guidance update, we are expecting a volume increase on the chipset obviously. There's a mix of products there. But on balance, we expect QCT to be contributing probably about $0.02 of earnings
componenttext: Okay, Tim, on the first part of your question, in terms of the guidance update, we are expecting a volume increase on the chipset obviously. There's a mix of products there. But on balance, we expect QCT to be contributing probably about $0.02 of earnings contribution. On the QTL side, we're looking for about $0.01 contribution. The OpEx is about $0.015 or $0.01 offset. And then, you got a tax rate increase for about $0.01. So I think that's about -- makes up your quarter-to-quarter, Q3 to Q4 walk on the earnings.

headline: QUALCOMM Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, the non-handsets?
componenttext: And then, the non-handsets?

componenttextpreview: The amount of handsets?
componenttext: The amount of handsets?
